name: 李曉祺
objective:
This class starts from the review of random process to the topics of detection and estimation theories. The following is a rough description of the material covered in this class.
1. Bayesian hypothesis testing
2. Minimax hypothesis testing
3. Neyman-Pearson and composite hypothesis testing
4. Bayesian parameter estimation 
5. Nonrandom parameter estimation
6. Maximum likelihood estimation
7. General/Linear Bayesian Estimation
schedule:
Week 1: Introduction
Week 2: Review of Random Variables
Week 3: Hypothesis Testing
Week 4-5: Bayesian Hypothesis Testing
Week 6: Minimax Hypothesis Testing
Week 7-8: Neyman-Pearson and Composite Hypothesis Testing 
Week 9: Midterm
Week 10: Bayesian Parameter Estimation 
Week 11: Nonrandom Parameter Estimation
Week 12-13: Maximum Likelihood Estimation
Week 14-15: General Bayesian Estimation
Week 16-17: Linear Bayesian Estimation
Week 18: Final
(subject to change)


Students who enroll in this course are required to have programming skills (Matlab or Python) in order to complete various experiments involving detectors and estimators. They will also develop related analytical abilities.
scorePolicy:
Midterm 30%
Final 30%
Homework 10%
Term Projects 20% (Matlab or Python)
Class Participation (Project evaluation) 10%
materials:
Textbook -  
H. Vincent Poor, An Introduction to Signal Detection and Estimation, Springer-Verlag N.Y., 1998.

Reference - 
1. Fundamentals of Statistical Signal Processing Volume I: Estimation Theory, Steven M. Kay,  2001.
2. Fundamentals of Statistical Signal Processing Volume II: Detection Theory, Steven M. Kay,  2001.
3. Probability and Stochastic Processes: A Friendly Introduction for Electrical and Computer Engineers, Roy D. Yates and David Goodman, 2004.
4. Random Signals: Detection, Estimation and Data Analysis, K. Sam Shanmugan and Arthur M. Breipohl, 1988.
5. Detection of Signals in Noise, Robert N. McDonough and A. D. Whalen, 1995.
